Fields.DialogueText: I think an illness may be starting to spread around the ship, Captain.
An illness? You're a doctor now?
No, but I can recognize the signs. Flushed face, trouble speaking, a great deal of sweating. Actually, now that I think about it, there may have been something in that letter.
What letter? I think you should start from the beginning.
An officer received an envelope. As soon as he opened it, he turned bright red and started sweating.
I asked him about it and he just sputtered some nonsense and ran away. Now that I'm thinking about it, poison is looking more likely.
It doesn't sound like poison to me. At least not yet. Did you see what was in the message?
Just a letter and a picture. Some woman making kissy face to the cameraman. I see, that could've been the kiss of death. We may be under attack.

Fields.MenuText: It's not poison, Maury. He got a letter from someone special and you just embarrassed him.
You're really smart, Maury. But sometimes you can be pretty dumb.
You're not far off, but we're not under attack. Love can just feel like that sometimes.

Fields.DialogueText: I embarrassed them? Oh, I see, I interrupted a private moment.
Dumb?! No one has ever accused me of being dumb, Captain. Nobody.
Love? Oh... yeah, I guess that could make sense too.
Do you know anything about romance, Maury?
I mean... I've researched it. But I've never experienced it myself first hand. Maybe I need to brush up on the subject.
That explains it. Well don't go bothering that officer. He's got enough on his mind.
Fine, I won't. There are other ways to learn about love.
@BATTLE
... Oh, boy.
*ALARM*
What's that, Maury? Did you get a letter?
Oh, yes. It's from my very best friend, Enterprise. We try to write to each other when we have time.
The aircraft carrier.
The very one! She's an incredible Belle, Captain. One of the few I can stand.
You don't get along with the other Belles?
Most of them just don't take all of this seriously enough. I mean, this is a war.

Fields.MenuText: That doesn't mean you can't try to have a little fun.
You're right. We need to focus on ending this war as soon as we can.
I don't think that's true. I've met other serious-minded Belles.

Fields.DialogueText: Fun has nothing to do with it. The war effort should still be the top priority.
I knew you'd see things my way. If only those flighty Belles could understand
Well, I haven't. Not many, anyway. But hearing you say that gives me a little hope for us.
So what did Enterprise write to you about this time?
I'm not sure, I haven't read it yet. Let's find out.
About what?
She's asking about you? Wants to know what I think of you.
I'd be interested in knowing that too.
Well... I think you're doing an excellent job as the captain.
Oh, stop. You're making me blush.
@BATTLE
... Oh, what's this? Why would she ask me about that?
*ALARM*
Maury? What are you... reading there? Doesn't look like your normal kind of book.
Oh, I was just doing a little research.
That's definitely not a textbook. It looks more like a novel.
I'll admit, it's not what I usually read, but you can't learn much about love and romance from the usual sources.
You're researching romance? Seems a little out of character for you.
True, it's hardly a pressing matter, but what you said before got to me. How could I have thought that officer was sick? It's so obvious in hindsight.
So what exactly have you learned from your research?
A lot of conflicting facts. Actually, you might be able to clear some things up for me.
I can do my best.
I've read from multiple sources that being in love is like having a stomach full of butterflies. How can you tell the difference between love and, say, indigestion?

Fields.MenuText: Simple. You know when it's love.
Hmmm... Actually, in my experience one can often lead to the other?
They're nothing alike. It's just a metaphor.

Fields.DialogueText: That's not a helpful answer at all!
You mean you can get a stomach ache by falling in love? And you can fall in love because you ate something bad? Love sounds confusing.
I know what a metaphor is. But I've never been in love, so metaphors are all I've got.
You really have no experience with this stuff, huh?
Well, when was the last time you heard about a ship falling in love?
Good point.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Captain, I meant to ask you something before. Have you ever been in love?

Fields.MenuText: A few times. I've actually been told I fall in love too easy.
I was in love once. Once. Didn't end well.
I can't say I have. One day maybe, just not yet.

Fields.DialogueText: Interesting. There must be a lot I could learn from you on the subject then.
Really? Sounds like I'm talking to the right person then.
So we're alike in that way. That's strangely comforting.
Why do you ask, Maury?
Well, while researching romance I came across the subject of heartbreak. My curiosity piqued, I wanted to hear a firsthand account.
Stories like that... a lot of people don't like reliving them.
So you're saying I might have to coax someone into telling me about their horrible breakup stories? Excellent idea, Captain.
That is not what I was suggesting.
Then how would you suggest I learn more about real life heartbreak?
Let's just hope you stay blissfully ignorant on this one subject.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
You still researching love there?
No, I'm taking a break from that particular subject. This is actually a recent study on space. Interested, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like a tremendous waste of my time.
Sure, I'm always up for learning something new.
Maybe if you explain it to me really slowly.

Fields.DialogueText: If you're learning something new, then you're never wasting time.
Fantastic. I can loan it to you when I'm finished. Shouldn't take me much longer.
It's not that complicated. It's just some advanced astro---actually... you might have to read through it a few times before you really absorb any of the information.
You're always either working on the war effort or you've got your nose buried in a book. Don't you ever do anything for fun?
This is what I do for fun.
What about when you need to blow off steam or something?
If studying doesn't work, I'd usually go to you to do that.
Hmmm... Yeah, that checks out.
Sometimes when Enterprise and I get together, things can escalate. Though that's usually her fault.
Oh, really? She likes to get you in trouble?
Not intentionally. It's just that when we're finally reunited, shenanigans ensue.
I'll remember to keep an eye on you two if I ever catch you on the same deck.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Captain, this never happens to me, but I need your help finding something that I've misplaced.
You've misplaced something? You're right, that really doesn't sound like you.
You don't have to remind me. One of my vintage compasses is missing from its spot on my shelf.
Oh, right, your little collection of old navigational tools.
When you put it like that, you make it sound so unimportant...

Fields.MenuText: I apologize, that was not my intention.
Well, in the scope of things, Morganas take precedence over ancient compasses.
You're right, now I remember. Your collection definitely isn't little.

Fields.DialogueText: If you find my compass all will be forgiven.
I... I know you're right, I'd just really like to find it.
Now you're making it sound like I'm weighing down the ship with my hoard of trinkets.
Does this compass really mean so much to you?
I can survive without it... I don't need it, but... it completes my collection.
Hmmm, actually that's kind of romantic.
What?
It completes you. Maybe all that studying you've been doing on romance is starting to take effect.
I'm not romantically interested in my compass!
That's not what I was trying to say. Come on, let's just go look for it.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Well... later.
That's a pretty decorative... tablecloth you've got there?
Tablecloth? No, this is a nautical chart of the area. You've seen these before, Captain.
Sure, just usually not in the mess hall. You can understand my confusion.
No, not really. Why would I be focusing so hard on a tablecloth?
That's a good point. You should be eating instead of focusing. I don't want you passing out from hunger on me.
I don't have time to eat right now, Captain. If I don't have this prepared in time, the Morganas could have the jump on us.

Fields.MenuText: Multitask. Eat and work.
Fine, go hungry. Just don't say I didn't warn you.
Come on, you have to eat something. I can hear your stomach growling for this food.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Fine, I suppose I can manage that.
I'll eat when I'm finished. I promise. You don't have to worry.
The sound of a stomach growling is actually from it digesting food you've already eaten. Since I haven't eaten in... I'm not quite sure how long, there's no way you can hear mine growling.
You know, I always see you working on these charts, but I've never quite understood it.
Really? Well, if you're interested in learning, I'd be happy to walk you through it.
Sounds fun. But can we eat first?
All right, you've convinced me. A quick bite and then it's back to work...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Captain, what are your plans for after the war?
That's a little presumptuous. If we don't stay focused, we could all be dead after the war.
I know, I'm just a little curious. Indulge me. Let's presume we win the war, what are your plans for life? What's important to you?

Fields.MenuText: Well, I'd probably stay in the navy and prepare for the next war. Another one is inevitable.
I think I'd like to settle down at some point. Maybe start a family.
Drink and celebrate. What else do you do after winning a war?

Fields.DialogueText: That's a horrible way to think about it. I'd like to think humanity is capable of peace.
A family? I can see you raising kids. You'd make a great parent.
You're not wrong, but I meant more in the long term.
So what brought on this new round of questioning?
One of the books I was reading. It had a very open ending. Made me start thinking about my own future.
Was it a romance novel?
Yes. Not many physics textbooks leave you with an open ending.
Well, what do you think you'll do after the war?
I want to do lots of things... Pursue scientific discoveries, spend as much time with Enterprise as I can, maybe even fall in love.
Those sound like some great plans.
I just wish I knew if I could do them all or not.
You can. And you will. We just have to win a war first.
Oh, is that all? Don't say that like it's a small thing!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Maury, looks you've got a letter. I'm guessing from the big "E" on the envelope that it's your friend writing back.
Yeah, that's Enterprise. And it's funny that you say that, Big E is actually one of her nicknames.

Fields.MenuText: Why does that seem like a kind of insulting nickname?
Oh, would you ever go by Big M?
That's awesome, I've always wanted a nickname!

Fields.DialogueText: It's not an insult. She wears all of her nicknames with pride.
Mmm... doesn't really seem fitting, if you ask me.
Well, you can't just ask for one. You have to earn a nickname.
All right, let's see how she responded to my letter.
Oh, right, wasn't she asking about me in her last letter? What'd you end up telling her?
Well, that's between me and her. I can tell you that I asked for some advice on my recent studies.
You mean your studies into love and romance?
Yeah, I figured she might have some insight.
... And?
Well, I can't read it with you here looking over my shoulder. A little privacy please?
You read the last one with me here.
That was different. Just go.
Fine, I'll leave you to it, I guess.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
It looks like trash to me. You should probably just toss it out.
Really? But it looks really old. I mean, this could be an artifact from some lost civilization! It could be worth thousands!
Or it's a piece of junk that fell out of a garbage can. And now you're getting trash particles all over your hands.
Ew.
Do I want to know what this is all about?
Oh, Captain, sorry if we're in your way. I was just advising him to get rid of some trash he found on the ground.
I still don't think it's trash. It looks like it's some kind of... device? It has a purpose, I'm certain!
Not one that I can see.
It looks kinda like a compass to me actually.
That's it! It's a compass! A compass from a lost civilization!
What is up with you and lost civilizations?

Fields.MenuText: He's right, though. And if I don't return it to where it's supposed to be. The apocalypse will begin.
Can I have it? I think I know who lost it.
I've actually been looking for that! Thank you so much for finding it for me!

Fields.DialogueText: Please, don't encourage him. I have to listen to his nonsense all day.
Someone's actually looking for this thing?
Seriously? You've been looking for this?
Just give it here, if you please.
As long as you promise to bring it home safe.
Of course.
Oh, I never got your names. I need to know who to thank for finally finding this.
Officer Hansen, Captain.
Call me Gabe!
That is not how you introduce yourself to a captain.
I'm just trying to keep it casual.
It's fine, thank you both. I'll be sure to pass it on to this thing's rightful owner.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Maury, I think I've got something to make you really happy.
Really? What is it? A book?
A book? That's what would make you happy right now?
I just finished reading that report. For the time being I'm out of study materials.

Fields.MenuText: Well, that kinda takes the wind out of my sails.
Sorry, I don't have a book for you, but we can fix that next time we make port.
What I have is even better than some stupid book.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, no - it shouldn't! I'm still very excited to see what you have for me.
It's nothing to worry about. New discoveries often come from rereading.
A stupid book? That's an oxymoron. Books are filled with knowledge.
How long are you going to hide whatever it is behind your back?
No longer.
My compass?! Where'd you find it?!
I actually found two officers squabbling over what to do with it. An Officer Hansen and... Gabe.
I'll have to find them and thank them myself, but I need to thank you too. I've been praying that it'd come back to me since the moment I lost it.
I'm just glad I could help.
The least I can do is buy you dinner some time.
Or win this battle.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Miss Maury, I just don't think any good can come from an area of study like that.
The new information should be reason enough. It's a scientist's duty to fight ignorance!
Sometimes ignorance really is bliss.
That's asinine.
What's going on here? I can hear the arguing from my office.
Oh, I'm sorry, Captain. I didn't intend to create such a disturbance.
You're Hansen, right? I didn't give you his name so you could yell at him, Maury.
I'm not yelling at him. I only approached him to thank him for finding my compass. Then we... got into a passionate discussion.
It sure felt like yelling to me...
I was trying to get my point across.
I understand your point, and I admit you may even be correct, but if Morganas really have emotions, then I just think we're better off not knowing.
You're arguing about Morganas? And their feelings?
More specifically the emotional capabilities of our foe. This one here refuses to even consider that they may be more than just monsters.
I just don't think any good can come from humanizing them. The last thing we need are Morgana sympathizers.
What do you think, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I think Hansen is right. We don't need to know what, or if they feel. We just need to know they bleed.
I suppose researching what exactly makes them tick couldn't hurt. It could lead to discovering a weakness.
How about we all just pretend I never stepped into this conversation?

Fields.DialogueText: If they're more than just mindless beasts, then we could do more than just fight them. We could understand them. That's the first step to defeating your enemy.
Precisely my point! I'm glad you can see the bigger picture, Captain.
It's a little late for that, Captain. You're not going anywhere.
Look, I can't control what you research, I just think it's a bad idea.
Lucky for me I don't really care what you think.
I honestly don't think I've ever seen Maury that upset.
Yeah, I've been told I have that effect on women.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I see you're keeping yourself busy there. Is it work, fun, or study?
All of the above, actually. I'm going over all we know about the Morganas. Looking for signs of anything we might've missed.
Right, you're looking for signs of them having feelings? This idea kinda came out of nowhere didn't it?
Well, it's just something I started thinking about while I was researching romance. It might lead nowhere, but I want to pursue it for now.

Fields.MenuText: You've been researching a lot of strange things lately.
I think it's pretty interesting. Mind if I join you for a bit?
Sounds boring, you should just do something more fun.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps. I just study what I'm interested in.
Oh, I suppose. I should warn you though, this is the really monotonous part. I enjoy it, but not everyone is a fan.
This is what I consider fun. A pile of reports is far more entertaining for me than hitting a ball with a stick.
Hey, Maury, I've been wanting to ask you something for a bit.
You want to ask why I'm so suddenly concerned with emotions, don't you?
I'd be lying if I said I wasn't curious.
Honestly? I'm just feeling things that I haven't experienced before. I was looking for a little insight. Now my curiosity is just getting the better of me.
I suppose that makes sense. Sometimes I forget that you're a ship.
Yeah...
So did you find that insight you were looking for? Do you understand your feelings better?
A little, but I feel like every answer brings new questions.
Sounds about right. Welcome to humanity.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Captain, I require your assistance with my romantic studies once again.
How can I refuse a request like that? What do you need?
In the text I'm reading, the main character is attempting to "attract" the object of their romantic interests.
You sure know how to make a romance novel sound like a school textbook.
Thank you. My issue is that I don't understand the thought process. Why must one go through this ritual of attracting your target?

Fields.MenuText: A lot of people are afraid of rejection, so instead of making the first move, they try to entice the other person into doing it.
You're asking the wrong person here. Do I look like some kind of master of attraction to you?
Well, the chase is half the fun. If romance was easy, you'd get bored with it.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm, that's actually a very good point. It makes a little more sense now.
You're not unattractive, if that's what you're implying. You're actually quite attractive, Captain.
People find being romantically spurned entertaining? I'm starting to think I'll never understand romance.
Well, do you have any other questions?
No, I'll have to go to another source for more diversity in my information gathering.
Maybe Enterprise can help.
I've already asked her actually. Maybe that imbecile Hansen will have some input.
Oh, actually there was something I wanted to bring up with you. I still owe you dinner for finding my compass.
I haven't forgotten. Maybe-
*ALARM*
Morganas!
We'll have to talk about dinner later. Come on, let's go.
@BATTLE
Oh, sorry, Captain, I didn't see you there.
It's all right. Don't mind me. Especially when you seem so cheerful. Were you skipping?
Heh, I may have been. I just got some good news while I was praying.

Fields.MenuText: Whatever the news is, I'm just glad you're happy. That adorable smile of yours is contagious.
It... it wasn't from the big guy upstairs himself, was it?
Good news or no, let's try and avoid a head on collision in the halls.

Fields.DialogueText: My smile is... adorable? I've never been told that before...
No, God didn't give me good news. That's not usually how prayer works.
Of course, I'm sorry. I really didn't mean to be so inconsiderate. It won't happen again!
So are you going to tell me what the good news was?
Oh, well, it's a little embarrassing, but I just received your message. That you're free to have dinner with me.
You just received that? That was supposed to get to you a while ago.
The crew knows I don't usually like to be interrupted during my services. There are exceptions though. Like this.
Well, I'm glad you're excited. I'm really looking forward to it.
Me too. So much!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
How are you enjoying your meal, Captain?
It's about as nice as the food is onboard can be, but the best part is the company.
I feel the same...
Um, Captain, is this just dinner? Or is this dinner?

Fields.MenuText: Did you just have a stroke? Did I? It sounds like you just said the same thing twice.
Well, if you want this to be something more, it's really up to you, Maury.
I mean... I thought it was dinner... but now I'm thinking it isn't?

Fields.DialogueText: Listen for the emphasis, Captain. I've read that the proper emphasis can change the subtext of a conversation.
I... it's up to me? Really? This dinner just got a lot more stressful for me.
It would seem you may be as confused as me. I'm a little glad actually.
Maybe we should eat first and ask questions later?
Is this a date, Captain?
A date? Okay. Sure, why not?
Why not? That's your reply? And here I thought I was the one that didn't understand romance.
That's not what I meant, I was just a little taken aback. I'd love for this to be a date.
... Really?
Yes. Now how about we start over.
I'd like that. More firsthand experience with this can only help my research.
Excuse me?
Well, the main character recently just went on a date. And the text didn't go into too much detail of what that activity actually entailed.
So you're using this to fill in some gaps?
More or less. I need to know all I can.
That makes a lot more sense. All right, let's show you what would happen on a date.
Do you mind if I take notes?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Captain, I had a wonderful time with you during dinner.

Fields.MenuText: I did too. It was a fantastic night.
It felt a bit more like I was giving a lesson than going on a date.
Yeah, dinner really is the best meal of the day. Especially when it's breakfast.

Fields.DialogueText: It really was. And I thought, after my research, that a date would be a struggle for me. It didn't feel that way.
I know, right? A night where I learn something new is really the best thing I can imagine.
I... suppose, but I was referring more to the time we spent together than the food itself.
However I still feel like there's so much I don't know. Do you think we could do it again?
I'm not so sure about that, Maury.
What?! Why not?
I just don't know how I feel about being your dating guinea pig.
Well, anything would sound bad if you put it like that.
Look, I just don't think it's a good idea. Sorry. I'll talk to you later.
Hmmm... am I doing this attracting thing wrong? This might require further research.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I just want to meet someone special, you know?
You mean someone who doesn't hate you for your abrasive personality?
You don't have to put it like that. I'm not horrible, I've just never really been good with relationship stuff.
Eh, perk up, bud. You've still got time to meet the one. Let's just hope you notice how she feels for you. We don't want another Pauline.
Pauline? What do you mean?
Remember Pauline from high school? She was head over heels for you, bud. And you were completely oblivious.
She was?!
Seriously? You still had no idea?! Ha! How dumb can ya get!?
I don't believe you. It's obvious when someone likes you, right. You can't miss something like that!
You seriously know nothing, buddy. Sometimes women are coy. You have to be really perceptive to notice when women aren't being direct.
Hmm, so it's possible that one can completely misinterpret the attempts at attraction for disinterest?
Oh, Miss Maury, how long have you been there?
Long enough. Please answer my question.
Yeah, lots of people don't pick up on signs and hints. That's why I'm always direct when I've got the hots for someone!
Is that really something to be proud of?
Thank you. The two of you have given me a lot to think about.
No problemo, Maury, happy to help.
Happy to help with what?
Oh, Captain, greetings. It's nothing you need to concern yourself with.

Fields.MenuText: You know I'm not going to drop it that easily.
Okay, I didn't really care anyway.
Don't make me order you to tell me.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, and I'm sure you know I'm not going to tell you that easily.
Really? Then why did you ask?
You would really do that? You must really want to know.
*ALARM*
Oh, look at that, we've got Morganas.
Can't you take anything seriously? We need to head to our stations.
You're right about that. Let's head out!
@BATTLE
Captain, do you not find me appealing?
I'm sorry? I think I must have misheard you.
Physically, do you find me repulsive?
You're not repulsive. What would make you think that?
I recently discovered that people have "types" that they are attracted to. I was merely trying to surmise what yours was.
That was a weird way of asking it.
I thought asking directly might seem rude. But now that we've come to this point, do you have a type, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I don't believe in types. I think they're a little too limiting.
Smart, funny, beautiful, supportive, brave, driven... I know, I have high standards.
I don't think I have a type... I just want someone that likes me, I guess.

Fields.DialogueText: So when it comes to romance, you have very eclectic tastes. I see.
High standards aren't the worst thing. And I'm sure you'll find someone that meets your criteria.
That's all it takes? Well, I suppose you're easy to please at the very least.
What about you, Maury? Do you have a type?
I think I do, Captain.
Well, what is it?
I... You're actually my type. Honestly, I'm embarrassed.
Excuse me? I think I might've misheard you again.
You didn't. I think that you'd be my type, Captain.
*ALARM*
This is just about the worst time for Morganas!
We'll take care of them quickly then.
@BATTLE
Is that another letter, Maury? What's the latest news from Enterprise?
I asked her for some advice, hoping she'd be able to suggest a new course of study.
You mean with your romance research.
Yes, it's rapidly becoming my main focus, but I seem to have hit a dead end in the area of attraction.
Are you saying you've learned everything there is to know about attraction?
No, it's more that I didn't quite find what I was looking for in my studies. Enterprise suggests I move my focus to something called seduction next.
Uh... Enterprise is suggesting you seduce someone?
I don't know much about the subject, but I take it by your reaction, that you disagree with her?

Fields.MenuText: Yes! You're too precious and innocent to go around seducing people!
I mean, you can do what you want, it just seems to be a big jump forward.
Actually, it could be a useful skill. Historically, seduction has been a successful tactic in war.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not quite sure what you mean by that, but I certainly know too much to be considered innocent.
Really? So it would be like skipping a few grades? I like that idea, but what if I miss some basic, crucial lesson because of this?
Ah, I think I know what you mean. I read something recently about a smile that could launch a thousand ships. That could be a useful skill.
Who exactly does Enterprise want you to seduce anyway?
Hmm? Oh, I uh, I doubt she wants me to seduce anyone. She, uh, probably just wants me to research it.
Well, just don't start practicing your seduction techniques on the crew, okay? We need them focused on the war.
Don't worry, I wasn't even thinking about seducing the crew.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Maury, you needed to see me?
Oh, yes, thank you for joining me.
Yeah, it's no problem. What's with all the candles?
I was just trying to set the mood.
The mood? Is that why everything smells like... flowers?
The candles are scented. Do you not like it? I can put them out!

Fields.MenuText: No, it's a nice scent.
Bleh, I think I might be allergic.
I'm just a little confused is all.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you like it. I had it picked up last time we made port.
To candles or flowers? Oh, never mind! I'll just get rid of them.
Are you really? I thought I was being fairly obvious.
So... what did you need me for, Maury?
Maybe I just wanted to talk to you. Here, you can take a seat next to me.
On your bed?
There's plenty of room.
... Okay, I think I know what's going on here. This is more studying, isn't it? This is just you testing what you've learned about seduction?
You're not enjoying it? I knew this wouldn't work! Stupid Enterprise!
Maury, I know you're trying to learn about love and emotions and stuff, but I already told you I don't want you using me to test stuff out.
But... what if I...
Just be yourself with me. Okay, Maury? I've got work to do. I'll see you later.
... Wasn't testing stuff out... Darn, why do emotions have to be so freaking hard?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Hey, Cap, you're looking a little gloomy over here.
You're... Gabe, right?
Hey, you remembered my name! I'm flattered. Now why don't you tell uncle Gabe what's bothering ya.
I'm just trying to keep my distance from Maury for a bit.
Why would you want to do that? You guys are always hanging out together. I thought you were pretty close.
Actually, there's talk around the ship that the two of you are a bit of an item.
Seriously? She's just been researching romance and feelings. She's just been testing what she's been learning on me. That's all.
She's testing romance on you? Either she's crueler than I thought, or you're dumber than you look.

Fields.MenuText: Are you calling me an idiot?
Maury isn't cruel, she's just calculating.
Maybe I am an idiot, because I don't see what you're getting at.

Fields.DialogueText: No, I'd never say that, Captain. I'm implying it.
Exactly. So she wouldn't be cruel enough to play with your emotions like that.
Oh, am I actually the smart one for once? This is new.
Just get to your point.
I'm thinking Maury might be getting romantical about you.
That's ridiculous.
And I know you've got some feelings for her. I can see these things.
... I just... I don't think she feels that way about me. And even if she does, I'm not sure she understands it.
Maury's a smart one. She understands it. She just might not know what to do with her feelings. You might just have to take the first move.
The first move being?
Tell her how you feel. Man, you might be more dense than Hansen.
... You might not be as dumb as you look.
Careful, I'm gonna get a big head if you keep complimenting me like that.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Captain, I need to talk to you. It's urgent.
Actually, I need to talk to you too. I've been thinking-
Please, allow me to go first. I feel like I haven't been clear enough with you, and I'd like to correct that now. I find myself having romantic feelings... toward you.

Fields.MenuText: Gabe was right.
I don't believe it.
No you don't.

Fields.DialogueText: Gabe? I tell you I'm interested in you and you think of Gabe? My research did not prepare me for this.
I know, I found it hard to understand at first as well.
I do. I know how I feel. Even if these feelings are new and confusing.
You're not just researching how people react to confessions or something?
I'm not confessing my feelings for you because of research.
In fact, all of my research has been so I could... well, figure out how to progress in a romantic relationship with you. I believe this to be the best way.
So... this I'm not just a guinea pig?
You were never a guinea pig.
Now... this is usually when you tell me how you feel about me.
*ALARM*
Captain? Can't you hear the alarm? Usually this is when you start getting ready for battle.
... What?
Snap out of it! We have Morganas to fight.
@BATTLE
Maury! There you are. I've been looking all over the ship for you.
Really? I'm sorry, I may have... been avoiding you.
Why would you avoid me?
Rejection. The scariest thing that I learned about in my research. Heartbreak can truly crush souls. According to my text.
You think I'm going to reject you?
I was worried you might. You didn't seem to be happy when I told you how I felt.

Fields.MenuText: It was a lot to take all at once.
Of course I was happy! I was ecstatic!
Honestly? I'd never been confessed to before.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, that's one of the reasons I was trying to attract you. I wanted you to confess first. That's how it happened in the books I studied.
You were? Because it looked more like you were having a stroke.
Really? By how often it was done in the books I studied, I figured it was a fairly regular occurrence.
Maury, I feel the same way about you.
You do?
Yes, that's why I didn't like helping you with practice dates. I didn't think you felt how I felt.
I never really considered them practice dates, Captain. I was just glad to be with you.
Well, then let's have a second non-practice date.
I'd love to.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
This has been a wonderful date, Captain.
You realize you keep saying that word, right, Maury.
I like it, it's a good word. I'm going to keep saying it. Date. Date. Date.
You know, I'm starting to like the sound of it too. Date.
So, Captain...
Yes?
When are we getting married?
Excuse me, what?!
Married. Most of the books I used to study romance ended in the main characters getting married.
That or death. And I can't die now. I have far too much I still need to do.
That's taking things a little- scratch that, a lot fast. I mean, we just started dating, not to mention we're still in the middle of a war.
So what about after the war ends?

Fields.MenuText: Then we can talk about it.
Sure. After the war we can get married.
Don't get ahead of yourself, Maury.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmmm... Fine, one more reason to eradicate these Morganas.
Really? Fantastic! My first romance and it's a complete success. I knew all my research would pay off.
Okay, but if we end up killing ourselves in a tragic misunderstanding, you only have yourself to blame.
You know, there are plenty of steps between dating and marriage.
I assumed, but my texts weren't exactly thorough in some of their explanations.
Well, for one, we haven't even kissed yet.
Kissing? Oh, right... How could I forget that...
You're getting red. You're cute when you're embarrassed.
Stop teasing me. I've never kissed anyone before.
The night isn't over.
So forward! Where was this when I was trying to attract you?
